# Central dogma of molecular biology

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This article **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(March 2018)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
The **central dogma of molecular biology** is an explanation of the flow of
genetic information within a biological system. It is often stated as "DNA
makes RNA and RNA makes protein,"[1] although this is an oversimplification.
It was first stated by [Francis Crick](/wiki/Francis_Crick "Francis Crick") in
1958:[2]

“ | The Central Dogma. This states that once 'information' has passed into [protein](/wiki/Protein "Protein") it cannot get out again. In more detail, the transfer of information from [nucleic acid](/wiki/Nucleic_acid "Nucleic acid") to nucleic acid, or from nucleic acid to protein may be possible, but transfer from protein to protein, or from protein to nucleic acid is impossible. Information means here the precise determination of sequence, either of bases in the nucleic acid or of amino acid residues in the protein. | ”  
---|---|---  
— Francis Crick, 1958  
  
and re-stated in a _[Nature](/wiki/Nature_\(journal\) "Nature \(journal\)")_
paper published in 1970:[3]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Centraldogma_nodetails.png/160px-
Centraldogma_nodetails.png)](/wiki/File:Centraldogma_nodetails.png)

[](/wiki/File:Centraldogma_nodetails.png "Enlarge")

Information flow in biological systems

“ | The central dogma of [molecular biology](/wiki/Molecular_biology "Molecular biology") deals with the detailed residue-by-residue transfer of [sequential information](/wiki/DNA_sequencing "DNA sequencing"). It states that such information cannot be transferred back from protein to either protein or nucleic acid. | ”  
---|---|---  
— Francis Crick  
  
A second version of the central dogma is popular but incorrect. This is the
simplistic DNA → RNA → protein pathway published by [James
Watson](/wiki/James_Watson "James Watson") in the first edition of _The
Molecular Biology of the Gene_ (1965). Watson's version differs from Crick's
because Watson describes the two-step (DNA → RNA and RNA → protein) pathway as
the central dogma.[4] While the dogma, as originally stated by Crick, remains
valid today, Watson's version does not.

The dogma is a framework for understanding the transfer of
[sequence](/wiki/Sequence "Sequence") [information](/wiki/Information
"Information") between information-carrying [biopolymers](/wiki/Biopolymer
"Biopolymer"), in the most common or general case, in living
[organisms](/wiki/Organism "Organism"). There are 3 major classes of such
biopolymers: [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") and [RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA") (both nucleic
acids), and [protein](/wiki/Protein "Protein"). There are 3×3=9 conceivable
direct transfers of information that can occur between these. The dogma
classes these into 3 groups of 3: three general transfers (believed to occur
normally in most cells), three special transfers (known to occur, but only
under specific conditions in case of some viruses or in a laboratory), and
three unknown transfers (believed never to occur). The general transfers
describe the normal flow of biological information: DNA can be copied to DNA
([DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA replication")), DNA information
can be copied into [mRNA](/wiki/MRNA "MRNA")
([transcription](/wiki/Transcription_\(genetics\) "Transcription
\(genetics\)")), and proteins can be synthesized using the information in mRNA
as a template ([translation](/wiki/Translation_\(genetics\) "Translation
\(genetics\)")). The special transfers describe: RNA being copied from RNA
([RNA replication](/wiki/RNA-dependent_RNA_polymerase "RNA-dependent RNA
polymerase")), DNA being synthesised using an RNA template ([reverse
transcription](/wiki/Reverse_transcriptase "Reverse transcriptase")), and
proteins being synthesised directly from a DNA template without the use of
[mRNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA "Messenger RNA"). The unknown transfers describe: a
protein being copied from a protein, synthesis of RNA using the [primary
structure](/wiki/Protein_primary_structure "Protein primary structure") of a
protein as a template, and DNA synthesis using the primary structure of a
protein as a template - these are not thought to naturally occur.[3]

## Biological sequence
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Biological sequence information")]

Main article: [Primary structure](/wiki/Primary_structure "Primary structure")

The [biopolymers](/wiki/Biopolymer "Biopolymer") that comprise DNA, RNA and
(poly)[peptides](/wiki/Peptide "Peptide") are linear polymers (i.e.: each
monomer is connected to at most two other monomers). The
[sequence](/wiki/Sequence_\(biology\) "Sequence \(biology\)") of their
monomers effectively encodes information. The transfers of information
described by the central dogma ideally are faithful,
[deterministic](/wiki/Deterministic "Deterministic") transfers, wherein one
biopolymer's sequence is used as a template for the construction of another
biopolymer with a sequence that is entirely dependent on the original
biopolymer's sequence.

## General transfers of biological sequential
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: General transfers of biological sequential information")]

[![Cdmb.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Cdmb.svg/256px-
Cdmb.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Cdmb.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Cdmb.svg "Enlarge")

     Table of the three classes of information transfer suggested by the dogma General | Special | Unknown  
---|---|---  
DNA → DNA | RNA → DNA | protein → DNA  
DNA → RNA | RNA → RNA | protein → RNA  
RNA → protein | DNA → protein | protein → protein  
  
### DNA
replications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: DNA replications")]

Main article: [DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA replication")

In the sense that DNA replication must occur if genetic material is to be
provided for the [progeny](/wiki/Offspring "Offspring") of any cell, whether
[somatic](/wiki/Somatic_cell "Somatic cell") or [reproductive](/wiki/Germ_cell
"Germ cell"), the copying from DNA to DNA arguably is the fundamental step in
the central dogma. A complex group of proteins called the
[replisome](/wiki/Replisome "Replisome") performs the replication of the
information from the parent strand to the complementary daughter strand.

The replisome comprises:

  * a [helicase](/wiki/Helicase "Helicase") that unwinds the [superhelix](/wiki/Superhelix "Superhelix") as well as the [double-stranded DNA helix](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_double_helix "Nucleic acid double helix") to create a [replication fork](/wiki/Replication_fork "Replication fork")
  * [SSB protein](/wiki/SSB_protein "SSB protein") that binds open the double-stranded DNA to prevent it from reassociating
  * [RNA primase](/w/index.php?title=RNA_primase&action=edit&redlink=1 "RNA primase \(page does not exist\)") that adds a complementary RNA primer to each template strand as a starting point for replication
  * [DNA polymerase III](/wiki/DNA_polymerase_III "DNA polymerase III") that reads the existing template chain from its 3' end to its 5' end and adds new complementary nucleotides from the 5' end to the 3' end of the daughter chain
  * [DNA polymerase I](/wiki/DNA_polymerase_I "DNA polymerase I") that removes the RNA primers and replaces them with DNA.
  * [DNA ligase](/wiki/DNA_ligase "DNA ligase") that joins the two [Okazaki fragments](/wiki/Okazaki_fragments "Okazaki fragments") with [phosphodiester bonds](/wiki/Phosphodiester_bonds "Phosphodiester bonds") to produce a continuous chain.

This process typically takes place during [S phase](/wiki/S_phase "S phase")
of the [cell cycle](/wiki/Cell_cycle "Cell cycle").

###
Transcription[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Transcription")]

[![Central Dogma of Molecular Biochemistry with
Enzymes.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Central_Dogma_of_Molecular_Biochemistry_with_Enzymes.jpg/256px-
Central_Dogma_of_Molecular_Biochemistry_with_Enzymes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Central_Dogma_of_Molecular_Biochemistry_with_Enzymes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Central_Dogma_of_Molecular_Biochemistry_with_Enzymes.jpg
"Enlarge")

Main article: [Transcription (genetics)](/wiki/Transcription_\(genetics\)
"Transcription \(genetics\)")

Transcription is the process by which the information contained in a section
of DNA is replicated in the form of a newly assembled piece of [messenger
RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA "Messenger RNA") (mRNA). Enzymes facilitating the
process include [RNA polymerase](/wiki/RNA_polymerase "RNA polymerase") and
[transcription factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription factor"). In
[eukaryotic](/wiki/Eukaryote "Eukaryote") cells the primary transcript is
[pre-mRNA](/wiki/Precursor_mRNA "Precursor mRNA"). Pre-mRNA must be
[processed](/wiki/Post-transcriptional_modification "Post-transcriptional
modification") for translation to proceed. Processing includes the addition of
a [5' cap](/wiki/5%27_cap "5' cap") and a [poly-A tail](/wiki/Polyadenylation
"Polyadenylation") to the pre-mRNA chain, followed by
[splicing](/wiki/RNA_splicing "RNA splicing"). [Alternative
splicing](/wiki/Alternative_splicing "Alternative splicing") occurs when
appropriate, increasing the diversity of the proteins that any single mRNA can
produce. The product of the entire transcription process (that began with the
production of the pre-mRNA chain) is a mature mRNA chain.

###
Translation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Translation")]

Main article: [Translation (genetics)](/wiki/Translation_\(genetics\)
"Translation \(genetics\)")

The mature mRNA finds its way to a [ribosome](/wiki/Ribosome "Ribosome"),
where it gets [translated](/wiki/Translation_\(genetics\) "Translation
\(genetics\)"). In [prokaryotic](/wiki/Prokaryotic "Prokaryotic") cells, which
have no nuclear compartment, the processes of transcription and translation
may be linked together without clear separation. In
[eukaryotic](/wiki/Eukaryotic "Eukaryotic") cells, the site of transcription
(the [cell nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus")) is usually separated
from the site of translation (the [cytoplasm](/wiki/Cytoplasm "Cytoplasm")),
so the mRNA must be transported out of the nucleus into the cytoplasm, where
it can be bound by ribosomes. The ribosome reads the mRNA triplet
[codons](/wiki/Genetic_code "Genetic code"), usually beginning with an AUG
([adenine](/wiki/Adenine "Adenine")−[uracil](/wiki/Uracil
"Uracil")−[guanine](/wiki/Guanine "Guanine")), or initiator
[methionine](/wiki/Methionine "Methionine") codon downstream of the
[ribosome](/wiki/Ribosome "Ribosome") binding site. Complexes of [initiation
factors](/wiki/Initiation_factor "Initiation factor") and [elongation
factors](/wiki/Elongation_factor "Elongation factor") bring
[aminoacylated](/wiki/Aminoacylation "Aminoacylation") [transfer
RNAs](/wiki/Transfer_RNA "Transfer RNA") (tRNAs) into the ribosome-mRNA
complex, matching the codon in the mRNA to the anti-codon on the tRNA. Each
tRNA bears the appropriate [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") residue
to add to the [polypeptide](/wiki/Peptide "Peptide") chain being synthesised.
As the amino acids get linked into the growing peptide chain, the chain begins
folding into the correct conformation. Translation ends with a [stop
codon](/wiki/Stop_codon "Stop codon") which may be a UAA, UGA, or UAG triplet.

The mRNA does not contain all the information for specifying the nature of the
mature protein. The nascent polypeptide chain released from the ribosome
commonly requires additional processing before the final product emerges. For
one thing, the correct folding process is complex and vitally important. For
most proteins it requires other [chaperone proteins](/wiki/Chaperone_protein
"Chaperone protein") to control the form of the product. Some proteins then
excise internal segments from their own peptide chains, splicing the free ends
that border the gap; in such processes the inside "discarded" sections are
called [inteins](/wiki/Intein "Intein"). Other proteins must be split into
multiple sections without splicing. Some polypeptide chains need to be cross-
linked, and others must be attached to
[cofactors](/wiki/Cofactor_\(biochemistry\) "Cofactor \(biochemistry\)") such
as haem (heme) before they become functional.

## Special transfers of biological sequential
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Special transfers of biological sequential information")]

### Reverse
transcription[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reverse transcription")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Extended_Central_Dogma_with_Enzymes.jpg/550px-
Extended_Central_Dogma_with_Enzymes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Extended_Central_Dogma_with_Enzymes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Extended_Central_Dogma_with_Enzymes.jpg "Enlarge")

Unusual flows of information highlighted in green

  

Main article: [Reverse transcription](/wiki/Reverse_transcription "Reverse
transcription")

Reverse transcription is the transfer of information from RNA to DNA (the
reverse of normal transcription). This is known to occur in the case of
[retroviruses](/wiki/Retrovirus "Retrovirus"), such as [HIV](/wiki/HIV "HIV"),
as well as in [eukaryotes](/wiki/Eukaryote "Eukaryote"), in the case of
[retrotransposons](/wiki/Retrotransposon "Retrotransposon") and
[telomere](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere") synthesis. It is the process by which
genetic information from RNA gets transcribed into new DNA.

### RNA
replication[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: RNA replication")]

RNA replication is the copying of one RNA to another. Many viruses replicate
this way. The enzymes that copy RNA to new RNA, called [RNA-dependent RNA
polymerases](/wiki/RNA-dependent_RNA_polymerase "RNA-dependent RNA
polymerase"), are also found in many eukaryotes where they are involved in
[RNA silencing](/wiki/RNA_silencing "RNA silencing").[5]

[RNA editing](/wiki/RNA_editing "RNA editing"), in which an RNA sequence is
altered by a complex of proteins and a "guide RNA", could also be seen as an
RNA-to-RNA transfer.

### Direct translation from DNA to
protein[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Direct translation from DNA to protein")]

Direct translation from DNA to protein has been demonstrated in a cell-free
system (i.e. in a test tube), using extracts from _[E.
coli](/wiki/Escherichia_coli "Escherichia coli")_ that contained ribosomes,
but not intact cells. These cell fragments could synthesize proteins from
single-stranded DNA templates isolated from other organisms (e,g., mouse or
toad), and [neomycin](/wiki/Neomycin "Neomycin") was found to enhance this
effect. However, it was unclear whether this mechanism of translation
corresponded specifically to the genetic code.[6][7]

## Transfers of information not explicitly covered in the
theory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Transfers of information not explicitly covered in the
theory")]

### Posttranslational
modification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Posttranslational modification")]

Main article: [Post-translational modification](/wiki/Post-
translational_modification "Post-translational modification")

After protein amino acid sequences have been translated from nucleic acid
chains, they can be edited by appropriate enzymes. Although this is a form of
protein affecting protein sequence, not explicitly covered by the central
dogma, there are not many clear examples where the associated concepts of the
two fields have much to do with each other.

###
Inteins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Inteins")]

Main article: [Intein](/wiki/Intein "Intein")

An intein is a "parasitic" segment of a protein that is able to excise itself
from the chain of amino acids as they emerge from the ribosome and rejoin the
remaining portions with a peptide bond in such a manner that the main protein
"backbone" does not fall apart. This is a case of a protein changing its own
primary sequence from the sequence originally encoded by the DNA of a gene.
Additionally, most inteins contain a [homing
endonuclease](/wiki/Homing_endonuclease "Homing endonuclease") or HEG domain
which is capable of finding a copy of the parent gene that does not include
the intein nucleotide sequence. On contact with the intein-free copy, the HEG
domain initiates the [DNA double-stranded break
repair](/wiki/DNA_repair#Double-strand_breaks "DNA repair") mechanism. This
process causes the intein sequence to be copied from the original source gene
to the intein-free gene. This is an example of protein directly editing DNA
sequence, as well as increasing the sequence's heritable propagation.

###
Methylation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Methylation")]

Main article: [Epigenetics](/wiki/Epigenetics "Epigenetics")

Variation in [methylation](/wiki/DNA_methylation "DNA methylation") states of
DNA can alter [gene expression](/wiki/Gene_expression "Gene expression")
levels significantly. Methylation variation usually occurs through the action
of DNA [methylases](/wiki/Methylase "Methylase"). When the change is
heritable, it is considered [epigenetic](/wiki/Epigenetic "Epigenetic"). When
the change in information status is not heritable, it would be a [somatic
epitype](/wiki/Somatic_epitype "Somatic epitype"). The effective information
content has been changed by means of the actions of a protein or proteins on
DNA, but the primary DNA sequence is not altered.

###
Prions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Prions")]

Main article: [Prion](/wiki/Prion "Prion")

[Prions](/wiki/Prion "Prion") are proteins of particular amino acid sequences
in particular conformations. They propagate themselves in host cells by making
[conformational
changes](/wiki/Protein_conformation#Levels_of_protein_structure "Protein
conformation") in other molecules of protein with the same amino acid
sequence, but with a different conformation that is functionally important or
detrimental to the organism. Once the protein has been transconformed to the
prion folding it changes function. In turn it can convey information into new
cells and reconfigure more functional molecules of that sequence into the
alternate prion form. In some types of prion in [fungi](/wiki/Fungi "Fungi")
this change is continuous and direct; the information flow is Protein →
Protein.

Some scientists such as [Alain E.
Bussard](/w/index.php?title=Alain_E._Bussard&action=edit&redlink=1 "Alain E.
Bussard \(page does not exist\)") and [Eugene Koonin](/wiki/Eugene_Koonin
"Eugene Koonin") have argued that prion-mediated inheritance violates the
central dogma of molecular biology.[8][9] However, [Rosalind
Ridley](/wiki/Rosalind_Ridley "Rosalind Ridley") in _Molecular Pathology of
the Prions_ (2001) has written that "The prion hypothesis is not heretical to
the central dogma of molecular biology—that the information necessary to
manufacture proteins is encoded in the nucleotide sequence of nucleic
acid—because it does not claim that proteins replicate. Rather, it claims that
there is a source of information within protein molecules that contributes to
their biological function, and that this information can be passed on to other
molecules."[10]

### Natural genetic
engineering[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Natural genetic engineering")]

[James A. Shapiro](/wiki/James_A._Shapiro "James A. Shapiro") argues that a
superset of these examples should be classified as [natural genetic
engineering](/wiki/Natural_genetic_engineering "Natural genetic engineering")
and are sufficient to falsify the central dogma. While Shapiro has received a
respectful hearing for his view, his critics have not been convinced that his
reading of the central dogma is in line with what Crick intended.[11][12]

## Use of the term
"dogma"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Use of the term "dogma"")]

In his [autobiography](/wiki/Autobiography "Autobiography"), _[What Mad
Pursuit](/wiki/What_Mad_Pursuit:_A_Personal_View_of_Scientific_Discovery "What
Mad Pursuit: A Personal View of Scientific Discovery")_ , Crick wrote about
his choice of the word _[dogma](/wiki/Dogma "Dogma")_ and some of the problems
it caused him:

> "I called this idea the central dogma, for two reasons, I suspect. I had
> already used the obvious word [hypothesis](/wiki/Hypothesis "Hypothesis") in
> the [sequence hypothesis](/wiki/Sequence_hypothesis "Sequence hypothesis"),
> and in addition I wanted to suggest that this new assumption was more
> central and more powerful. ... As it turned out, the use of the word dogma
> caused almost more trouble than it was worth. Many years later [Jacques
> Monod](/wiki/Jacques_Monod "Jacques Monod") pointed out to me that I did not
> appear to understand the correct use of the word dogma, which is a belief
> _that cannot be doubted_. I did apprehend this in a vague sort of way but
> since I thought that _all_ religious beliefs were without foundation, I used
> the word the way I myself thought about it, not as most of the world does,
> and simply applied it to a grand hypothesis that, however plausible, had
> little direct experimental support."

Similarly, [Horace Freeland Judson](/wiki/Horace_Freeland_Judson "Horace
Freeland Judson") records in _The Eighth Day of Creation_ :[13]

> "My mind was, that a dogma was an idea for which there was _no reasonable
> evidence_. You see?!" And Crick gave a roar of delight. "I just didn't
> _know_ what dogma _meant_. And I could just as well have called it the
> 'Central Hypothesis,' or — you know. Which is what I meant to say. Dogma was
> just a catch phrase."

## Comparison with the Weismann
barrier[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Comparison with the Weismann barrier")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Weismann%27s_Germ_Plasm.svg/330px-
Weismann%27s_Germ_Plasm.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Weismann%27s_Germ_Plasm.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Weismann%27s_Germ_Plasm.svg "Enlarge")

In [August Weismann](/wiki/August_Weismann "August Weismann")'s [germ
plasm](/wiki/Germ_plasm "Germ plasm") theory, the hereditary material, the
germ plasm, is confined to the [gonads](/wiki/Gonad "Gonad"). Somatic cells
(of the body) [develop afresh](/wiki/Embryology "Embryology") in each
generation from the germ plasm. Whatever may happen to those cells does not
affect the next generation.

The Weismann barrier, proposed by [August Weismann](/wiki/August_Weismann
"August Weismann") in 1892, distinguishes between the "immortal" germ cell
lineages (the [germ plasm](/wiki/Germ_plasm "Germ plasm")) which produce
gametes and the "disposable" somatic cells. Hereditary information moves only
from [germline](/wiki/Germline "Germline") cells to [somatic
cells](/wiki/Somatic_cells "Somatic cells") (that is, somatic mutations are
not inherited). This, before the discovery of the role or structure of DNA,
does not predict the central dogma, but does anticipate its gene-centric view
of life, albeit in non-molecular terms.[14]
